text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for review of the new Andrew
Jackson jihad record Christmas Island
Christmas coming early this year hey you
know good try betting on that not really
a good joke they did shut up
Andrew Jackson jihad Arizona band that
I've been following for a little while
now this is their latest full-length LP
out on side one dummy records if you
give a listen to their stuff expect to
hear some Punk flavored folk or what
some people would call anti folk and
artistically and in terms of recognition
Andrew Jackson jihad comes out ahead of
a lot of bands that also get this label
and I think it's for a few reasons for
one the last few records have been
taking on heavier more ambitious just
harder hitting production which i think
has brought the emotional impact of
their songs so much higher but even
strip back Andrew Jackson Jihad's tracks
still have a lot of punch thanks to the
depressing sad bitter and clever
lyricism of their frontman Sean bonnet
his voice is not for everybody it's kind
of a weakling voice but he does embrace
this flaw wholeheartedly and I think
uses it to his advantage to catch catch
catch catch to give his lyrics a certain
kind of tone and even though he's not
the most technically skilled singer ever
he does have a very good grasp of folk
song writing and punk energy
I just find his lyrics to be incredibly
thought-provoking smart witty and there
are a few songwriters out there that I
think as well as him depict this sad
hilarity in just really terrible
situations addiction racism hate
depression family people who are lonely
the downtrodden the self-center the
self-loathing to me sean songs are just
perfect depictions of the highs and the
lows of the human condition and just
really obsessed with it with the two
extremes so with their most ambitious
album yet knife man directly behind them
I was anticipating this latest record
wondering what they're going to do next
would there still be a lot of personal
stories and fears delivered on this
record what the production still be
really grand going into this record I
had
these questions and and maybe they
weren't the best questions to have
because this is my least favorite Andrew
Jackson jihad records since their debut
and it's for a few different reasons but
the main one comes down to production
and instrumentation this new record of
theirs is put together so methodically
and so plainly that there's very little
in the way of drama or finesse coming
from the guitars from the really generic
piano embellishments that happen
throughout the cell P and the drumming -
it just all feels so incredibly reserved
and doesn't really reflect the emotional
wreck that Sean and these songs really
are instrumentally this is Andrew
Jackson jihads most middle-of-the-road
record yet the song Temple Grandin that
opens this hashed up while I don't mind
this track songwriting wise I think it
is one of the better songs on the entire
record the track instrumentally just
feels so flat and distorted and
compressed it kind of sounds like I'm
listening to the mountain goats do a
Neutral Milk Hotel cover like how in
1945 or something like that it's just
not really a flattering sound for Andrew
Jackson jihad while I guess they wanted
to make a song that just buzzed and was
kind of rough around the edges there's
like no momentum there's no
explosiveness to the instrumentation on
this thing
I feel like there's kind of a limit to
the fidelity on tracks like I want to
rock out in my dreams - which tries to
have these really explosive crescendos
backed up by these grand tubular bells
what sound like tubular bells not only
is the instrumentation on this track not
that grand but this song features some
of Sean's biggest lyrical potholes like
saying I miss you and I can even rhyme
that with kiss you a lyric whose
self-awareness doesn't really save it
for being a cringe-worthy moment it's
really like Andrew Jackson jihad was
trying to write their pop record on this
album or at least an album that feels
better than other Andrew Jackson jihad
releases the most self-deprecating
moment on this entire LP is the closer
where Sean is talking about how he's a
salad glove he's the Forever Lazy he's
this pointless and useless and worthless
thing that shouldn't be saved which is
nowhere near the level of personal
suffering that's been displayed on
previous releases I mean to me the best
song in this entire record is Linda
constat which is this track where sean
is is talking about losing his and
just crying and being moved deeply by a
beautiful piece of art in a museum
lyrically it's a hilarious song but this
track in a way is sort of about
something positive and that's fine
there's nothing wrong with making
positive music and music should not
simply be valued by whether or not it
makes you sad or how much the singer
hates himself or just how authentically
depressing the music feels in my head
what I'm thinking of is what emotion is
being depicted and how well does it
depict it but while this album doesn't
really seem like a depressing record
that's angrily pointing its bony-ass
finger at the world's flaws it's not
really a record you would put on if you
wanted to be in a good mood either
because there is still a lot of just
very disturbing lyricism on this LP
which I will say is is most likely the
strongest thing this record has going
for it like on the refrain to the song
Temple Grandin which defined a nicer way
to kill it coda is absolutely genius if
you google who Temple Grandin is I like
the lyrical theme on the song Kokopelli
face tattoo about all these horrible
things that won't necessarily suck any
less just because you hate them so why
waste the energy and getting naked
playing with guns is a great track as
well and weirdly enough lifts a melody
from the cars track just what I needed
tastefully and I love the very morbid
imagery that comes into play on the
songs all the suicide and all the cult
themes that are on that track or played
out in the same sort of sad yet
hilarious way that I typically expect
and enjoy in Andrew Jackson jihad songs
sean is definitely still a riveting and
a passionate storyteller with a lot of
flair and a lot of personality but I
also think on these tracks on this
record overall there are more non
sequiturs than usual - that don't really
add up into the theme of the song at
least as to how I interpret it anyway
and let me also say there are some
tracks on here that try things different
with instrumentation and with sound for
Andrew Jackson jihad real left hooks for
them but I think they are severe misses
on this record some of my least favorite
Andrew Jackson jihad songs ever like the
song coffin dance which
to me sounds like a really lackluster
shoo-shoo song or the track deathless
where I think Shawn is really pushing
his vocal abilities to sing kind of this
desert rock tune with these elongated
vocal harmonies over the chorus what do
you have you know this record starts off
relatively strong finishes with two
really good tracks but it's just
littered with tracks that I'm just
feeling are very very hit-or-miss
throughout the middle I'm feeling a
decent two strong five on this thing
unfortunately transition if you've given
this record of listen what did you think
of it did you love it did you hate it
why what do you think I should review
next and that's it Andrew Jackson jihad
Christmas Island forever
